title: WebView originWhitelist is not implemented
body:
### Environment

1. `react-native -v`: 0.57.1
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`: rnpm-plugin-windows@0.2.0
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`: react-native-windows@0.57.1
4. `node -v`: 10.15.0
5. `npm -v`: 6.4.1
6. `yarn --version: N/A

Then, specify:

<!-- (What platform are you building for? Choose any from UWP, WPF) -->
- Target Platform: UWP

<!-- (What framework version are you building for? Choose from 10.0.14393, 10.0.10586, 10.0.10240, etc. (UWP), .NET 4.6.1, .NET 4.5, etc. (WPF) -->
- Target Platform Version(s): 10.0.14393

<!-- (What device(s) are you targeting? Choose any from Desktop, Mobile (ARM), Mobile Emulator, Xbox, Hololens) -->
- Target Device(s): Desktop

<!-- Which operating system are you using? Specify macOS, Windows, or Linux, along with specific release versions -->
- Development Operating System: Windows

<!-- Which version of Visual Studio are you using? Specify Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2017 -->
- Visual Studio Version: 2017

<!-- Which build configuration are you running? Choose from Debug, DebugBundle, Release, ReleaseBundle -->
- Build Configuration: Debug (All)

### Steps to Reproduce

'originWhitelist`, as described in the React Native documentation (https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/0.57/webview#originwhitelist) is not supported in the React Native Windows implementation.

### Expected Behavior

The WebView component (`https://github.com/Microsoft/react-native-windows/blob/0.57-stable/Libraries/Components/WebView/WebView.windows.js`) should accept an `originWhitelist` prop similar to `https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/0.57-stable/Libraries/Components/WebView/WebView.ios.js` and match its functionality.

title: Question: how to force a layout update/collect extra updates from shadow node?
React-Native-Win32.dll should have proper Version
body:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Build react-native-win32.dll
(Result is "vnext\target\x64\Debug\React.Windows.Desktop.DLL\react-native-win32.dll")
1. Check its File Version and Product Version
  1. In Windows Explorer
  1. Right Click on react-native-win32.dll
  1. Click Properties
  1. Click Details

### Expected Behavior

Version should be dynamic, ideally match the one which is specified in the Git Tag
git tag | grep 0.59.0-vnext.171
react-native-windows_v0.59.0-vnext.171

Thus File Version should be something like:
0.59.0.171

### Actual Behavior

File Version is static and always:
1000.0.0.0
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/43590492/65444196-63504e00-dde4-11e9-93ed-5a1d1a93c95a.png)

title: Pointer events don't transfer focus to the Flyout on Open
body:
### Environment

react-native-cli: 2.0.1
react-native: 0.59.0-microsoft.73
extraneous: rnpm-plugin-windows@0.2.11
react-native-windows-repo@0.0.1
4. `node -v`: v12.1.0
5. `npm -v`: 6.9.0
6. `yarn --version`: 1.16.0

- Target Platform Version(s): 10.0.18362
- Target Device(s): Desktop
- Visual Studio Version: 2019
- Build Configuration: Debug, Release

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Load RNTesterApp in Playground
2. Navigate to <Flyout>
3. Click "Open Flyout" using mouse or touch 

### Expected Behavior
Keyboard focus should be transferred to the first focusable child of the Flyout. 

### Actual Behavior
Keyboard focus remains in the main window

### Additional context
This is a regression from https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/2817

title: Extract mapping of RN Accessibility to UIA from DynamicAutomationPeer

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body:
<!-- This is a template for new feature or API proposals for React Native Windows. Use this to submit new API/component requests or behavior updates that are specific to Windows-only. For feature requests to React Native, go [here](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals) instead. 

It's fine if you don't have all the details for the template below: you can start with the Summary and Rationale. Read more about React Native for Windows proposal process [here](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/tree/master/vnext/proposals)
-->

# Proposal: Extract mapping of RN Accessibility to UIA from DynamicAutomationPeer
<!-- Add a title for your feature or API proposal. Please be short and descriptive -->

## Summary
<!-- Brief explanation of the new API or change. -->
Right now, DAP is the only control that reads out the RN accessibility properties we set and translates them into UIA properties. Views are the only things that use it. We would have to subclass all of our native controls to use DAP which is bad for perf. 

Need to develop new story for custom automation peers for WinUI 3.0.

Project Universal.Integration tests lacks some UWP-specific functionality in its TestRunner implementation.

Finish implementing the test runner to the point the Dummy JS-driven integration test runs successfully in UWP.

title: Add C++/WinRT ABI to test DLL
body:
# Proposal: Add C++/WinRT ABI to test DLL

## Summary
`React.Windows.Desktop.Test.dll` is not ABI-safe.
Adding the C++/WinRT layer should fix this.

## Motivation

As we progress towards achieving ABI safety for `react-native-win32.dll`, the test DLL is a good starting point for experimentation.

title: Open touch keyboard for TextInput when getting focused in touch mode
body:
In iOS and Android, if you use a `TextInput` and it gets focused, the onscreen keyboard opens automatically. So if you navigate to a screen with an input, you can auto-focus it, that opens up the keyboard directly and the user can start typing.

With RNWindows, currently the input is focused but no keyboard is shown. This is fine for most applications, but if there is no keyboard connected, this means that the user has to click on an already focused input field to open up the keyboard.

With this implementation, the keyboard opens when the `UserInteractionMode` is touch. I also tried using the `KeyboardCapabilities`, but on the Surface 4 it also showed connected keyboards when there were none.

title: Update GettingStarted.md
body: I was getting an error until I went into Package.appxmanifest and under Capabilities check Private Networks (Client & Server).

title: [ThirdParty] Implement 'react-native link' for RNWCPP native plugins
body:
React Native developers use the `link` command to automate the process of updating build configurations to compile (or link) native dependencies for native modules and view managers. For example, if a developer wants to add a Map component to their React Native app, they may use [`react-native-maps`](https://github.com/react-native-community/react-native-maps). This package includes source code for the native platforms that must be compiled with the React Native app. The user experience looks something like the following:
```
yarn add react-native-maps
react-native link react-native-maps
```
The result of running the `link` command is that the Android gradle scripts and the iOS `.pbxproj` will be updated with references to the native dependencies.

We'll want to provide the same tooling for RNWCPP to integrate native dependencies from React Native packages in the OSS ecosystem.

title: React Native application window becomes blank screen when explorer.exe is restarted
body: When the explorer.exe is restarted, the react native windows screen becomes blank and application becomes not responsive, it only happens on Released app and MS suggestion to force the app to run on UI thread has temporarily fixed the problem, looking for a long term solution for the same.

title: Optimize unnecessary layout work

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body:
Andrew Coates says that we construct a yoga layout tree for a lot of nested Views which we let Yoga perform layout on, yet we must forcefully call Measure/Arrange (not sure which) on the backing XAML panels, otherwise we can't correctly push layout information into them.  This means we're paying a cost in XAML to run layout unnecessarily.

Can we optimize away this cost?  Thoughts:
-Attack the problem as directly as possible.  Requires debugging through XAML to find out why the explicit calls to layout are necessary.
-Change PanelView to Canvas?  Canvas pays a much lower cost to run layout
-Implement MeasureOverride/ArrangeOverride and do nothing?

title: Convert std:map usage to vector_map

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body:
XAML (windows.ui.xaml.dll) has a vector_map implementation that was profiled and shown to outperform std::map.  The API works identical to std::map so converting is purely mechanical/trivial.

This work item is to port vector_map into the codebase and replace usage of std::map

title: Animation perf analysis

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body: Animations in RN are all "dependent" as they tick on the UI thread.  Need to do some perf analysis to determine if this will result in glitchy animations, particularly for those that could potentially be done as "independent" animations (eg translation/opacity).

title: Evaluate RNWCPP works against Windows 8.1

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body: This is tracking evaluation of whether RNWCPP works against down-level Windows up to 8.1. Based on the investigation, we may need to open issues to track any work to shim for inbox API changes between windows versions.

title: RN's <View/> layers cleanly over the native framework

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body:
The matrix of what properties/behaviors are provided by XAML and what styling React Native's View supports don't line up well.  This is apparent in the case of borders (which makes up most of the [View Style props](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/view-style-props)).  Depending on which combination of properties are targeted by an app the current implementation has to manage various trees of XAML elements to get the desired effect with proper clipping of children, per edge border coloring and thicknes, rounded corners, etc.  

Given that <View> is such a fundamental type and widely used it is worth investigating how we can be more performant (e.g. flatten the native UI tree required).

title: react-native-windows interop with WinUI 3.0

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body:
With the planned upcoming release of [WinUI 3.0](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md) which will be the next version of the native Windows UI platform, it seems worth considering: 

1. react-windows-native core using WinUI instead of the older version of Windows::UI::Xaml

2. enabling using WinUI controls in native UI components/views

title: Implement flexbox layout using XAML panel

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body:
This came out of:
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/issues/2642

Today's implementation of flexbox runs layout mostly "outside" XAML layout, and then we set absolute positions on all XAML elements.  This has a number of downsides, most notably performance impact to do it correctly.

This issue is tracking implementing flexbox using XAML's layout engine, either by implementing a custom panel, or directly in XAML someday, instead of the current approach.

title: Enable JSI Unit Tests for Win32
body: We cannot use the publicly available win32 Google Test nuget right now since our win32 build uses a different calling convention. As a result, JSI unit tests are only running for x64 at the moment. We should figure out how to enable them for win32 as well.

title: Context Menus

milestone.title: WinUI3 (vNext M6)
milestone.description: This milestone builds upon MVP to leverage [WinUI 3](https://github.com/microsoft/microsoft-ui-xaml/blob/master/docs/roadmap.md#winui-3) to fill in the feature gaps and complete implementation of RNW core APIs.

body:
<!-- This is a template for new feature or API proposals for React Native Windows. Use this to submit new API/component requests or behavior updates that are specific to Windows-only. For feature requests to React Native, go [here](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals) instead. 

It's fine if you don't have all the details for the template below: you can start with the Summary and Rationale. Read more about React Native for Windows proposal process [here](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/tree/master/vnext/proposals)
-->

# Proposal: Add context menus to RNWCPP
<!-- Add a title for your feature or API proposal. Please be short and descriptive -->

## Summary
<!-- Brief explanation of the new API or change. -->

Context menus give users access to additional functionality related to onscreen items without cluttering the interface. React Native does not provide a component to display any kind of menus. The need to display contextual commands is common for many apps.

Unlike many UI components visible on apps' primary surfaces, context menus are supporting UI that appears temporarily. For that reason, I believe users expect context menus to have consistent look & feel across the entire OS rather than showing the unique branding of each app where context menus are used.

There are two primary questions that we need to address:
1. How will the context menu be attached to its parent component, triggered through user action, and positioned once it appears?
2. Will the context menu content be represented using a wrapped native control and if so, which one? 

## Motivation

<!-- Why are we doing this? What use cases does it support? What is the expected outcome? Why should this be done for Windows-only?

Please focus on explaining the motivation so that if this proposal is not accepted, the motivation could be used to develop alternative solutions. In other words, enumerate the constraints you are trying to solve without coupling them too closely to the solution you have in mind. -->

### Menus
**Windows** (proposed)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13142665/61166897-8c9e5500-a4ea-11e9-8506-e1b7e19e913d.png)

**Windows** (current)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13142665/61167011-d8ea9480-a4ec-11e9-853f-fbd35a514546.png)

**iOS**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13142665/61166840-8c518a00-a4e9-11e9-9b08-0df945549bb6.png)

**Android**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13142665/61166849-c589fa00-a4e9-11e9-86ef-9fd5f74f40cc.png)


### Edit menus
Text input fields have context menus that are visually and functionally distinct from general-purpose menus.

**Windows** (proposed)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13142665/61166915-020a2580-a4eb-11e9-9f65-e8ac549d110e.png)

**Windows** (current)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13142665/61167029-15b68b80-a4ed-11e9-838e-b351b29371c4.png)

**iOS**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13142665/61166927-282fc580-a4eb-11e9-8a8d-3ddc72ffef27.png)

**Android**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13142665/61167059-82318a80-a4ed-11e9-841f-cfaacbd6b464.png)
 
**Note:** RN's TextInput component includes a [contextMenuHidden](https://facebook.github.io/react-native/docs/textinput#contextmenuhidden) prop. I have not yet verified, but to me this implies that TextInput will show a **native** context menu for common commands like Copy/Paste. 

## Proposal
RNW should wrap native Xaml controls to show context menus on Windows.

**Pri 1**
* CommandBarFlyout
* AppBarButton
* MenuFlyout
* MenuFlyoutItem

**Pri 2**
* MenuFlyoutSubItem
* AppBarSeparator

**Pri 3**
* AppBarElementContainer
* AppBarToggleButton
* MenuFlyoutSeparator
* ToggleMenuFlyoutItem
* RadioMenuFlyoutItem

## Menu invocation

Windows users can invoke context menus using these "context actions":

Input | Context action
-- | --
Mouse | Right click
Keyboard | Shift+F10, Menu button
Touch | Long press on item
Pen | Barrel button press, long press on item
Gamepad | Menu button

Xaml's ContextFlyout property and ContextRequested event encapsulate all these context actions and trigger whenever users perform one of these actions.

## Basic example

<!-- [Optional] If the proposal involves a new or changed API, include a basic code example. Omit this section if it's not applicable. -->

## Open Questions

<!-- Please list any open issues that you think still need to be addressed.
These could include areas you think would benefit from community or the react-native-windows team input -->
1. What's the correct way of associating a context menu with the UI component from which it's invoked?
    - One proposal is to attach the context menu to its parent component, RNW should expose the `attachAsContextFlyout` prop for the wrapped CommandBarFlyout and MenuFlyout components.
    - Another alternative is to provide a `MenuTrigger` component similar to the approach used by [instea/react-native-popup-menu](https://github.com/instea/react-native-popup-menu)
    - **Resolved**: Add a View props event similar to HTML's [oncontextmenu](https://www.w3schools.com/jsref/event_oncontextmenu.asp)

- Adds the `ARM64` build platform for both Desktop and Universal.
- Bumps ChakraCore.Debugger dependency to `0.0.0.38`.
- Bumps OpenSSL dependency to `1.0.2-p.3`.
- Bumps react-native dependency version to `v0.59.0-microsoft.20`

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/2814)

title: [Releases] Document approach for shared native code dependencies
body:
For native common code dependencies from [facebook/react-native](https://github.com/facebook/react-native), we'll likely want to work off of a fork to avoid the need to block on releases of `react-native`. 

Here is a (likely incomplete) list of shared native code dependencies:
- [Folly](https://github.com/facebook/folly)
- [Yoga](https://github.com/facebook/yoga)
- [ReactCommon](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/tree/master/ReactCommon)

We'll need to decide if we want to take native common code dependencies through one of these mechanisms:
- Git submodules from main OSS repositories for each dependency
- Git submodule from a single native code fork
- Compiled binaries +/- package management
- Ad hoc copy-pasting of code into repo, or custom merge script
- Something else...

As far as I can tell, folly is the only native code dependency that isn't already inlined in react-native.

body:

This is 'the red screen' what I mean:

body:
Even with the hiccups i have encountered I am a big, big fan of RN-W.   It is the right approach... Finally!

What is needed is a set of repos supporting v59 or v60 that are able to be easily installed with the latest release.

Most of the repos for RN I have tried require expo or are not compatible with this release.  

I am willing to help put together and test  a list of the projects if someone can provide some input as to which ones work now, or could work with a bit of tinkering..

Nice work!  The finish line is within sight!

title: Various VS project config issues
body:
The builds of `packages/playground` should not need to rebuild `ReactCommon`, `ReactWindowsCore` and `ReactUWP` etc, if they have been built by `vNext/ReactWindows.sln`.

This is likely due to the solutions having different definitions for `outDir`.


We need to take another look at how our native projects are setup.
- [x] vNext currently overrides Directory.build.props, and does so in a way that prevents other users from being able to provide their own Directory.build.props
- [ ] We need to document and provide examples of how to configure a solution / project to use the correct variables (things like FollyDir and ReactNativeDir)
- [ ] We need to take into account that the directory structure may not have all packages directly under the projects node_modules folder.  When using yarn workspaces, packages are often hoisted up to a root node_modules folder
- [ ] The final structure should be as close to standard "new VS project" as possible.
- [ ] It needs to be compatible with the `run-windows` command, which has some coded requirements about final code output layout
- [ ] We should possibly add ways to configure `run-windows` to work with non-standard output layouts

title: React-Native linking of react-native-svg not working error generated
body:
React Native Environment Info:
    System:
      OS: Windows 10
      CPU: (8) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6700T CPU @ 2.80GHz
      Memory: 5.83 GB / 15.88 GB
    Binaries:
      Yarn: 1.7.0 - C:\Program Files (x86)\Yarn\bin\yarn.CMD
      npm: 6.9.0 - C:\Program Files\nodejs\npm.CMD

UWP

 10.0.14393, 

Desktop
 
  Visual Studio 2017  community  
 

 

(Write your steps here:)

1.install the attached zip file 
2.try and link (there will be a bug that i have a fix for below)
3.Even with the fix the linking of react-native-svg does not work

this bug is generated 
Invariant Violation: requireNativeComponent: "RNSVGRect" was not found in the UIManager.

This error is located at:
    in RNSVGRect (at Rect.js:22)
    in Rect (at App.windows.js:141)
    in RNSVGGroup (at G.js:23)
    in G (at Svg.js:127)
    in RNSVGSvgView (at Svg.js:116)
    in Svg (at App.windows.js:140)
    in RCTView (at View.js:45)
    in View (at App.windows.js:138)
    in App (at renderApplication.js:34)
    in RCTView (at View.js:45)
    in View (at AppContainer.js:98)
    in RCTView (at View.js:45)
    in View (at AppContainer.js:115)
    in AppContainer (at renderApplication.js:33)
 
on line 99 of  react-native/local-cli/link/link.js 

    if (!linkConfig || !linkConfig.copyAssets ) {
      return;
    }


should be

    if (!linkConfig || !linkConfig.copyAssets || !  project[platform]) {
      return;
    }

It fixes a bug but linking still does not take place  

[rnbugrepo.zip](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/files/3429299/rnbugrepo.zip)
